headline: CNN Tonight
subHeadline: SCOTUS Approved Congress Of Getting Trump's Tax Returns; Colorado Shooting Suspect Facing Multiple Charges; Fear And Cowardice Is Not An Option; Fans Saw What They Did Not Expect In World Cup; Questions Loom Why FIFA Handed World Cup To Qatar; Three Officers Arrested Over Violence Issue. Aired 10-11p ET

utterances.speaker: KASIE HUNT, CNN CHIEF NATIONAL AFFAIRS ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Thanks so much for watching. I'll be back here tomorrow night. I hope you will be too. Our coverage continues now with Alisyn Camerota. Hi, Alisyn.

utterances.speaker: ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: I'll be back here tomorrow night. Kasie watching. Great show.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: We'll see each other.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: OK. Fantastic. Thanks so much. Good evening, everyone. This is CNN TONIGHT. I'm Alisyn Camerota.The Supreme Court says Donald Trump's tax returns must be turned over to Congress. This is something the former president has been fighting for years. He took his fight all the way to the Supreme Court, and today they ruled against him. So, when might we see what's in his taxes? Our experts will get into that. And that's just one of the legal issues hanging around Trump that seems to be accelerating. But turnaround is fair play and the Republicans are planning a smerkish board of their own investigations that we will lay put for you. Plus, new information on the investigation into the Colorado Springs LGBTQ nightclub shooting. We have disturbing new details about the suspect's teenage years. And if you've ever played out in your own head what you would do in an active shooter situation, you're not alone. One of our guests tonight says, it's time to rethink the advice to run, hide, fight. We'll find out what she says to do. But let's start with Donald Trump's taxes. Here with me, our CNN senior legal analyst, Elie Honig, former Senator Al Franken and former Congressman Joe Walsh. Great to have all of you here. Elie, this is something he's been fighting for years. I mean, since 2015 when Donald Trump first was running for president, he promised he was going to turn over his taxes and show them to the American public, and he never did it. He claimed he was being audited. We have no idea. And now, what did the Supreme Court decide, and on what grounds today?

utterances.speaker: ELIE HONIG, CNN SENIOR LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Well, the Supreme Court said, you're out of luck, and those tax returns have to go over to the House Ways and Means committee. And this, in many ways, is the typical Donald Trump legal battle. Here's why. He got wiped out at every level of federal courts. Started in the district court lost there. District court says tax returns go over. Then he went to the court of appeals, three judges, three to zero says, Trump, you lose, Congress, you win.Then he tried to get the whole D.C. circuit to take the case. They said, no thank you. So still, he hasn't gotten a single judge. And then he tried to get to the Supreme Court, and today they issued a two-sentence ruling saying, nope, we're good. Not a single dissenter. So, he loses at every level. Yet as you said, Alisyn, what does he get? Delay? Here we are. This legal battle, in particular has been going on for over two years and there's a new Congress. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But doesn't have to happen now. I mean, now the IRS has to turn over, right?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes. They have to turn over. Of course, we're 40 some days though, from Congress flipping over to the House. I do want to say this though. If you look at the law that the House ways and means committee used to get these tax returns, it also says they have to keep individual tax returns even of a former president confidential. So, we should not expect to see them unless they are leaked, contrary to that law.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That's interesting. Because I was wondering when the American public would be able to see them.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: What could possibly be in there that he doesn't want us to see?FMR. SEN. AL FRANKEN (D-MN):  He's a criminal. You know, you know, you know when he said if I -- I could stand on Fifth Avenue and shoot somebody, I wouldn't lose any votes. He might have been right about that, but he would've been prosecuted for shooting someone. He's going to be prosecuted, he's going to be held accountable. Jack Smith is going -- we have a special prosecutor. He's going to be prosecuted.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: So those are different things. I mean, obviously that's for the January 6th investigation, as well as the holding of the classified documents.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And for he's going to be -- Georgia, I mean, how criminal is that? I need you to find me --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Let's pull this up.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: On tape.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And on tape.FMR. REP. JOE WALSH (R-IL):  Line them up. Line them up, Alisyn --

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And if you don't --

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: -- there are so many.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Let's pull them up just so that everybody can keep track. So here are the investigations that Donald Trump is involved in right now. What he's being investigated for. You were alluding to it, Senator. So, there's everything from the Manhattan D.A., the Trump Organization, the House ways and means tax probe, the Georgia election interference, as you were saying, the January 6 committee, of course.The DOJ is also looking into January 6th and whether he instigated the riot. DOJ, the classified documents that he hoarded at Mar-a-Lago, the New York attorney general, the fraud lawsuit. So, there's a lot that he's looking at. And you're saying, Senator, that he will be held accountable for something.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: God, yes. The only thing worse than prosecuting him is not prosecuting. He's going to be prosecuted.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: He has to.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: With his base. And I hear what you're saying. I remember when he was found with all of the classified and top-secret documents at Mar-a-Lago, and he had said something to the effect of, if they can do this to me, just think what they can do to you.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, if I had classified documents at my house, they would also do that to me. I found that logic to be so funny.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: You're right. But, Alisyn, Republicans rallied around him after that Mar-a-Lago. Just crazy.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: And I should say, we could be heading for a really unique moment in American history where you can have an active candidate, a leading candidate --

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: -- perhaps for president who is under indictment. I mean, there is a very real chance he's indicted by Fulton County, by the special prosecutor. And I want to say people assume sometimes if you're indicted, that means you're knocked out. No, it does not. You can be convicted of most crimes and still run for president. So, we could have a --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But which one of those that we just put up there do you think will come to fruition?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I think the two that are most likely, I think Fulton County has been given all indications that they're moving very aggressively and that they intend to indict --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Meaning the election interference in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes. And then the second thing is if we're looking at special counsel Jack Smith, I think they're more likely to indict on the Mar- a-Lago documents. So, we could see even two investigations. Again, who knows? But here's the thing to keep in mind, indictment is up to the prosecutor. Yes, you go to a grand jury, but prosecutors can get grand juries to indict whoever they want for the most part.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Ham sandwich.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: There is truth to that. Ham sandwich. There is some truth to that. But indictment is just the start. And you ask the question before, is there going to be accountability? It depends what you consider accountability. Indictment I think that's increasingly likely to happen. Conviction is going to be very powerful.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Well, just adjudication, I think that people would consider justice, adjudication for --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: It's better than nothing as the senator have said.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Elie, would there be -- would there be any accountability for January 6th in your mind. I mean, Donald Trump incited and led -- HONIG

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: -- a violent attempt to overthrow an American election.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I think Fulton County is increasingly likely to charge that, whether DOJ does, especially if Fulton County has charged, if you're sitting there at DOJ, you may say, well, they've got that piece. We'll do the documents. There's a lot of moving parts.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Can I talk about what Joe said, which is, yes, maybe it'll whip up his supporters, but his -- this last election, the American people said, stop it. Stop it. They said all the deniers in key races lost. Donald Trump, you know, maybe he'll get the nomination. Who knows? Because you know, all you need are 30 percent in primaries. If there's a big field.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: That basically started what, started him in '16. But I -- there is not -- I don't know if it's a majority of the Republican Party. Maybe it is.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: No, I hear what you're saying. And if voters said, stop the chaos. Then let's go to the next point, which is all of the investigations that Republicans are planning when they take back control of the House in January.So, I'll just tick through these. They want to know the origin of the COVID-19 pandemic. I'm glad this is a amazing to you, Senator.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: They want to know, Kevin McCarthy wants to know about China and investigate their theft of intellectual property, the conduct of health officials during COVID- 19, including Anthony Fauci, the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan, which was, you know, a disaster.January 6th committee situation at the southern border. The FBI, the IRS, they want to try to impeach secretary Mayorkas, depart -- Education Department officials and Hunter Biden. OK. Senator, go. What do you think of all of those?

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Well, I'd start with Hunter Biden because as I said, I think the American people said, stop it. But these, the Republicans are full of crazies or people who are just chicken. And I -- and McCarthy is, I think in the latter group. And yes, they'll do Hunter Biden and American people. They'll do exactly what the American people don't want them to do. Some of those are --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Legit.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: -- things that are legit. And you should -- you should look at, but you know Jim Jordan leading the judiciary committee in the House.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: This seems funny now that you're out of Congress, I assume this has been more amusing to you.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Jim Jordan.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Alisyn, Elie is right. my former party has been overtaken by crazies. Kevin McCarthy maybe speaker probably, but Marjorie Taylor Greene will be the de facto speaker. Period.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: For real?

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: For real.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: How will she be the speaker?

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: She will have such sway over him. I mean, look at what they've been emphasizing already. They're leading with all this crazy stuff. Why? Because McCarthy has to have Marjorie Taylor Greene and the rest of her crazies all lined up.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Because otherwise she'll tweet something. I mean, what's the downside? Why can't he alienate Marjorie Taylor Greene?

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Because he doesn't her to be the face of the party for the next two years. And if she doesn't get what she wants, Alisyn, she will become the face of the party.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: And Joe, one of the things --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: How long will she be speaker is the question?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes, she -- she's been talking about the I word, impeachment, right?

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Yes. And another.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: She's already drafted impeachment.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I didn't know that.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: It's only happened once, secretary of war in the 1870s and not since. So, they may be barking up the wrong tree if they go, but Mayorkas is going to be their first target, I think. CAMEROTA

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: You think they're going to?

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Well, that's what they're saying out loud, but I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Because they can focus on the border, the border, of the border.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: OK, gentlemen, thank you very much. Stick around. Great conversation. We have to talk about this. The Colorado Spring suspect is behind bars tonight and we're getting new accounts from survivors. But I'm sure that many of us have wondered what we would do in a horrifying situation like that.Our next security expert says the old run, hide, fight advice maybe outdated. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: JULIETTE KAYYEM, CNN NATIONAL SECURITY ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Well, look, fighting was always the last resort. I think the -- I think we just have to be honest about the evidence. And I just want to start with the beginning.We shouldn't be -- in a rational society we would not be having this conversation. How do you survive an AR attack in a confined areas, essentially the conversation that we're having. But if you're going to judge success by do fewer people die, the evidence is starting to show that engagement with the killer if you -- if you can't get out, because in these confined spaces you often can't, can decrease the harm. We've seen it. A great peril to the per -- to the person or people who are doing it, as we've seen in Colorado and as we've seen in other instances. So why does this matter? Because the run, hide, fight logo or the slogan. Everything people in my field believed in came out of 1999. It existed before, but really, Columbine. And that lesson was, the kids should get out or they should hide. But what happened when they hid in the -- in the library was that was where all the kids were killed. Two decades later, go to the Pulse nightclub when the -- when they died, most of the people who died, who were killed, were killed in the bathroom because they tried to hide there. And so, if running is not an option, it's not entirely clear hiding is a good option because of two realities. These mass shootings are happening more frequently and people are getting killed too quickly with this weaponry.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: And I want to be clear here. The statistics from the FBI as I wrote in the piece, are 70 percent of mass shootings end before the police can arrive, and 31 percent of them end after two minutes. I think that's what basically what happened in Colorado.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But Juliette, obviously it can't just be a one size fits all piece of advice.

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Because I'm not Richard Fierro. I mean Richard Fierro --

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- was a 15-year veteran. He's a big guy and he has that kind of metal where he ran towards the guy with the weapon of war. I, five three Alisyn, can curl --

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- into a very tight ball, very small, and I can hide --

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- more easily than Richard Fierro. And so, it's just hard for, I mean, first of all, like you say, I can't believe we're having -- we have to have --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: It's an absurd conversation.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But we do have to have this conversation --

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- because it's going through all of our heads. And so, isn't it just, you know, whatever you are capable of doing.

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's both. It's -- so what I, you know, what's the alternative, right? Is that it's both situational and personal. And so, you know, in these instances where, you know, you have a for -- a former vet who happens to be there, but you know -- but you know, thank God is willing to go forward.We've seen other instances where members of the public who are, don't have that kind of training are able to disarm or basically what we call it is you take the fight to the shooter. In other words, if you're able to distract them, what you're trying to do is buy time. That is what these guns have not given us. They do not give the victims time to run, and they do not give law enforcement time to come in. I am, as you know, been on the show many times about, you know, the capacity of these guns to kill quickly has changed everything because you -- the best law enforcement response. Forget the Uvaldes. The best law enforcement response is still going to take a minute or two. And I have to address something that's out there in response to this. There's very minimal evidence that arming more people, a good guy with a gun makes us safer. There are instances and people like me have to be honest about those instances. In Indiana mall earlier this year, there was a gunman who killed a potential mass shooter. But it is not that more guns are the solution. If that were the case, we'd be the safest country on earth. It is just that this is going to be situational now, especially in instances where the running is difficult.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Such a great point. There was an armed guard in Buffalo, you know, at the supermarket.

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: There was an armed guard at Parkland. You know, we've, I mean, obviously there were cops all over Uvalde, and so it just --

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- it just -- it just does show the illogic of that notion. Juliette Kayyem, thank you very much. Really provocative piece.

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: KAYYEM
utterances.sentences: Happy Thanksgiving.

utterances.speaker: ERROL LOUIS, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I mean, you know, I don't know if -- I don't know what to say about that. I mean, that's what he's now saying.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: It sounds like they're trying to prepare a defense against a hate crimes charge. That's the least of his problems legally speaking. But it looks like they're trying to build some kind of sympathy or at least confusion on the question of whether or not this was purely motivated by hate.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Such a, I mean, that is what it sounds like. We'll wait to see. Back to that conversation that I was just having with Juliette. Have you thought about that? I mean, have you had to think about what would I do in an active shooter situation?

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Well, we all have to, and that's the great tragedy of this situation we find ourselves in. As these gentlemen know we've been stuck legislatively on trying to get any kind of progress or serious solution to this. And what this does is it leaves the rest of us in a situation where we're going backwards in time.And by backwards in time I mean, back to the 17th century when, you know, Thomas Hobbes writes Leviathan and he's talking about a war of all against all. And the whole point of government is to make it so that we're not all forced to sort of fight for our lives at any given moment. But that's where we are heading. Make no mistake about it, and it's an outrageous situation that we find ourselves in. We haven't been able to legislate our way out of it. Frankly, you know, I mean, run, hide, or fight really applies politically. You can't run from this question, you can't hide from your responsibilities as a citizen or as a voter. And it is time to fight back.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: But Alisyn, what's so frustrating about this incident is, legislatively there was a law on the books (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The red --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: They had a red flag law. CAMEROTA

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: And it wasn't enforced. That county, El Paso County, Colorado, the law enforcement in that county has basically publicly said they're not going to enforce the red flag laws.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That's right. And also, furthermore, Joe, there -- it relies on the parents. It relies on the family saying, yes, I'll press charges against my son. We saw this in the Highland Park shooter as well. Often mothers don't want to do that, and so then police leave. And that is a loophole that we need to figure out in red flag laws.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: We -- we've seen an uptick, and I don't know about this, this person and this shooter and his situation, but there's been an uptick in hate crimes and there's been an uptick in hate in Republican politics. You know, don't say gay legislation. All that does is isolate people, vulnerable kids who are already isolated.We've seen uptick in anti-Semitic violence, in anti-Asian, in anti- LGBTQ, and it is exploiting hate for political purposes to get power. And it's very dangerous. And this is, I think part of, again, what American people want to want to stop.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I mean, and obviously everybody wants to stop mass shootings, but it's -- there's somehow, we've just accepted now that this is a part of our lives, that this is a part of our lives and somehow, we're all sitting ducks. So, our kids have to have active shooter trainings in their classrooms from the time they're in first grade. And we all have to figure out, OK, should we run or hide, or fight. Because, you know, every single week we report on a mass shooting.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Well, they are a fact of life. They need to be minimized. This guy should not have had a gun. My God, there was a bomb threat a year before against his mom. The law enforcement could have then taken his guns away.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I want to believe that.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: I can't.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I mean, I hope that I want to believe that. What we had been told is that it has to be adjudicated. You know, he has to have been like convicted or something.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: I think that's separate from the red flag law. The enforce --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I hope you're right.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: I just, why do we have assault weapons? Why? There's no reason for assault weapons. There's no reason to have them. It's insane. And the number of mass shootings, again, has gone up significantly. There's no reason at all. There's -- no one needs an assault weapon. No one needs it to go hunting. CAMEROTACongress to fight that.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And what the gun industry did was just make more effective assault weapons. The Sandy Hook was a bushmaster that was designed to kill people in close quarters.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. And so, I mean.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: It's sick.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: It is sick, but you know, they -- the Biden administration touts that they've had the first bipartisan gun legislation in 30 years. But I'm not sure that it gets to the heart of the --

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: It doesn't, it doesn't. I mean, and look, the 110th Congress like the several before it made a little bit of progress, but not much and not enough. I would predict broadly that the 116th or the 118th Congress when some of these kids who had been brought up with these shooter drills and bulletproof backpacks and all of the garbage that we have accepted as normal.When they get an opportunity, when they get into politics, when they get their hands on the levers of power, when they've got a trail of stories from Parkland all the way back to Columbine, I think they're going to get rid of all of this stuff.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: I don't think other -- I don't think other congresses have achieved anything. I know when I was there after Sandy --

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Big time.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: -- after Sandy Hook, it was amazing that we couldn't get background checks. Americans want background checks.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: At poll after poll. Poll after poll shows a --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: And that's --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- huge majority.

utterances.speaker: WALSH
utterances.sentences: And that's an area where both sides can -- should -- can and should come together in a nanosecond.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And it's amazing they can.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The excitement is growing for the U.S. versus England this Friday in the World Cup. Even with the controversies surrounding the games, fans are still showing up. So, what do we all need to know about the World Cup?Obviously, I could tell you, but I've decided to call in John Berman to explain it to all of us from the matches to the controversies. Berman?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: All right, back with me now Errol Louis, Al Franken, and suddenly John Berman. How did you get here so fast?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Fleet to foot.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Wow. Wow. That was great, John. You made us all smarter. That wasn't just a sports lesson, it was a history lesson, which I appreciate, but you didn't answer the most important question. Which player was Shakira's boyfriend?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: He -- Pique who played for --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, where's he?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: -- Spain but he's not on the team. CAMEROTA

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: This time around.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: No. Then I'm suddenly not interested in any of this.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: No, I'm sorry about that.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But you did tell me Catherine Zeta.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Catherine Zeta Jones is Welsh.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: A lot of people -- a lot of -- Wales is confusing to a lot of people because it's part of the United Kingdom, but it plays as its own country in the World Cup. So, I often tell people who are trying to understand, Catherine Zeta Jones. It helps.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: It helped me a lot.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Senator, are you following this with rap attention?

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: No, you're not.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: I -- it's a great sport.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: It is. It's the world. Very, very popular sport --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, I feel it.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: -- in the world.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I feel what you're saying.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: I played soccer in high school but --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: You should like it then.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: I should. We are terrible. We were, I mean, this is in, I graduated high school in 1969. We did not know how to play soccer in 1969 in America.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: How did you play it?

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: We, I just kicked this. I was a fullback, which is defense. I just kicked it as far as I could, every time. I just kicked it as far as I could. WALSH

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Look where -- and look where you are now.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Look where I am now.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Errol, forgetting the sport aspect of this for a moment, in terms of the controversies, has it been worth it to have it in Qatar?

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: I think so.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And why?

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Just from an educational standpoint. I mean, listen, you come to appreciate your freedoms when you see other people who don't have them. So, when you find out, you know, layer after layer that there's no freedom of speech. If you criticize the government, you can be in prison. There's no freedom of religion. You are not allowed to practice your religion except in a designated area in Qatar.There's, you know, you are not allowed to come in with alcohol or pork. You can't bring it into the country. It's a pretty rough place. It's a pretty sort of an old school, if you want to call it that, or pre-modern, almost frankly. As far as the Sharia law, the -- (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And all the LGBTQ --

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: -- restrictions.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The restrictions that we're seeing play out here.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Conversion therapy, floggings. I mean, it's a pretty brutal system to somebody who's familiar with how the freedoms that we take for granted in this country. And so, for that reason alone, it's really interesting to see how other people are living. Does that mean we should have not gone there to play? Does it mean that people should shun this nation?Well, when you start seeing the other countries out there that also have these kind of restrictions, it makes you realize that the freedoms that we take for granted are really, really.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Leave it to Errol to give us the silver lining on all of this, and I really appreciate that. I think that's true. It has all come to the fore. We've been talking about it now for a week in a way that we wouldn't have been.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Look, and like Qatar spent a lot of money to get the World Cup there because it wanted it to be, it's coming out party on the world stage and they may be getting the opposite of what they were after.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: The treatment of foreign workers there is just, that's an under told story. BERMANour friend who was over there doing reporting, did a whole expose on this where I talked to them undercover. It's really shocking. It's really shocking. The really, hundreds of thousands of workers brought in to do the work and how they're treated.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And what about the corruption for FIFA? Well, how did they choose Qatar?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, there have been all kinds of reports on this. It, you know, it's the money. I mean, there were -- there were accusations of flat-out bribery in some cases to get these World Cups. This one is in Qatar. Four years ago, it was in Russia.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: So, not a great record when it comes to things like, you know --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Next one in the U.S.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: The U.S. which hopefully would be vastly different.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Right.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: That was after everything was exposed is when the U.S. one was awarded.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: All right. Thank you for the lesson. Really interesting.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Nice to see you all.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The Supreme Court is in the news tonight after granting Congress access to Donald Trump's taxes, and the court is also the subject of one of Al Franken's podcast episodes. So, let's talk about it.So, Al, you are talking about the legitimacy of the court on your podcast with Dahlia Lithwick who writes about the Supreme Court for Slate. And what's the gist of what we're about to hear?

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: I think this is a conversation about when Clarence Thomas after Alito did Dobbs decision in his concurrence said that we should also revisit Griswold, birth control and Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And Obergefell. So same sex marriage, privacy and sex. He didn't do Loving. I think that's what we talk about, obviously. I think we joked about it. Dahlia is, writes about the Supreme Court for Slate and she's brilliant and I always have her on when we talk about the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: OK. Let's listen.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DAHLIA LITHWICK, WRITER, SLATE
utterances.sentences: Well, this was a tiny bit of a, like, Twitter freak out because everybody thought he was using it to get out of his own interracial marriage. And I think that's not quite correct.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Well, she's in trouble.

utterances.speaker: LITHWICK
utterances.sentences: The other case she is in trouble. It would -- it would solve the problem.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: So, he could say, yes, not legal. It was not legal.

utterances.speaker: LITHWICK
utterances.sentences: The problem of Ginny, I think that he explicitly named the three cases he said that are on the table are Obergefell, which is marriage equality. Lawrence v. Texas, which is the same sex intimacy, the anti-sodomy law in Texas, and Griswold, which is contraception, the right to use contraception in your marriage. He didn't name Loving.Well, Brett Kavanaugh like rings his hands in his concurrence and it's like, nobody worried. Nobody is coming for marriage equality. Nobody is coming to reinstate the Texas anti-sodomy laws. And of course --

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, stare decisis is so important. I remember him saying that in his hearing.

utterances.speaker: LITHWICK
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that the tell is when they tell you, we're not coming for the next thing, you should know that they're coming for it.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That's chilling. So, what's your conclusion about where we are with the Supreme -- where the Supreme Court is now?

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it's an illegitimate court. I was there when they didn't take up Merrick Garland and when they didn't, remember, when they didn't take them up, they said, it's an election year. And they decided -- they said it was a kind precedent. It wasn't. That never happened before.And then, of course, you know, four years later when we have Coney Barrett when Ruth Bader Ginsburg guys in late September, they write, they -- and Coney Barrett is sworn in like eight days before.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And that's what makes it illegitimate?

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. That's two stolen seats in my mind. And you know, and they've changed their -- they lie about it all the time. This is kind of what they do. That's what it was, as McConnell said, well, we're short been from votes cast from New Hampshire. Remember he said that and then -- and then --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Marveling at your impression. Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Well, and then, Coney Barrett, boom.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And you remember Lindsey Graham saying, like, if a seat comes open in 2020 --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: -- I will, we will not take up a nominee. And you can keep the tape.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Remember I said that?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I remember it. I mean, I remember all those imaginations, but in terms of the decisions they're making, obviously they overturned Roe versus Wade, but then they do something like allow Donald Trump's taxes to be seen by Congress. And then that makes people think, OK, maybe they're not all Trump appointees.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: OK. I mean, but kind of was a no brainer. And it's more about fulfilling this conservative, fundamentalist Christian kind of agenda. And that's why Trump won the election in '16 when he said, I'm going to let the Federalist Society pick the --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: -- pick the justices.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Pick these nominees. Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And that's exactly what he did.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: John?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm curious what you think the fix is though. If, for people who agree with you when you bring this up, how would you now fix it? Is it -- is it packing the court? Is it term limits for the justices? Do you think any of those are actually within reach?

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: No. I mean the term limits is a elegant solution, I think, which is given 18-year term limits, every president gets a 0.2. But, if you did that, that would be a slow walk to correcting the illegitimacy of the court right now. Now, there is another way to go, which is if it turns out, if we can prove that Alito leaked these things, his own opinion, and he leaked Hobby Lobby, which is, someone who's accusing him of maybe we could get rid of him. That'd be fun.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: It's interesting that, even bringing up these kinds of questions I think does affect the justices. They act as if they're, you know, completely removed. They don't care what any of us think. That's why they have lifetime tenure. But the reality is they do care what the public thinks. They don't want to be seen as a bunch of partisan hacks. They've --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: That's why Coney Barrett went to the McConnell Center to make the speech about how they're not partisan.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Well, that's right. I mean, and --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, the Democrats have gone to the McConnell Center also.

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Including Joe Biden has gone to the McConnell Center.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: But why go to the McConnell Center when you're making the point that we're not partisan, when he seated her nine days before the election.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: And on the principle, you can't have a -- you can't have a -- you can't --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, of course.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: -- nominating hearing for Garland.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Right. The double standard was glaring.

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Because people have already voted her in --

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean the point being people should speak out. If you want to go in march, you want to write a letter, you want to complain, you want to get on television and say, we, we think you're illegitimate. I think people should absolutely do that. They have to --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: FRANKEN
utterances.sentences: Where could I do that?

utterances.speaker: LOUIS
utterances.sentences: They have to know where -- they have to know where their limits are and that the public is watching what they do. And that things like some of the questions that have been raised about Ginni Thomas, Justice Thomas's wife, and her involvement in politics and what she might have done in and around January 6.Those are perfectly legitimate questions. If they want to sort of, play this aggressive kind of conservative legal politics, they should expect some pushback.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: You know what? They should also stop doing their jobs in secret. They should put cameras maybe in the Supreme Court so the American people can see what's going ugly in there --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I'd like that.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: -- and then make up their own minds about what's happening.
